OVERVIEW


To truly serve the customer, electric utilities must make great strides to provide reliable service, affordable rates and a stake in the utility process. The latter can be crucial for utilities as they seek to make system improvements with new generation or power delivery projects. It’s no secret that many infrastructure projects are delayed or stopped altogether due to public opposition. It is becoming clear that to successfully engage the public, utilities are moving beyond traditional approaches and employing a wide range of participation techniques. So, how can a utility build necessary infrastructure and improve relationships with stakeholders and regulators? What can the utility gain by engaging the public?
 
This EUCI conference will provide a forum for utility executives, regulators, customers and experts in public participation to discuss how utilities and their affected communities can come together to identify infrastructure improvements that all stakeholders can support. Attendees will learn how utilities are able to obtain meaningful input and how different approaches are used in order to overcome objections, reach out to traditional adversaries and improve relationships with community leaders and regulators.
 
The first session will be a comprehensive panel discussion among representatives from integrated utilities, transmission owners/operators, utility customers, regulators, alternative energy advocates and public involvement experts. This panel will address specific questions regarding the definitions of trust and transparency and how to create these attributes in the stakeholder involvement process. The panel will also speak to best practices from specific projects across the country and will conclude with a Q&A session from the audience.
 
The remainder of the conference will take this discussion into more specific focus. Utilities will talk about their company’s philosophy on public participation, their typical methodology, internal training and organizational responsibility. These presentations will also include case-specific examples of the public process for generation and power delivery projects and speak to the specific results, positive and negative, gained from the process.
 
What Attendees Will Learn:
 

How to identify and engage key individuals in a balanced conversation that produces positive outcomes

How to develop trust among all participants

What different stakeholders look for and expect in a meaningful process

How to collaborate with leaders in your community, including traditional "opponents"

How to generate recommendations and build public support

How to significantly improve relations with regulatory officials


Who Should Attend:
 

Utility employees with regulatory and local affairs 
responsibilities

Project managers

Regulators and regulatory staff

Power consumer representatives

Community groups

NGO representatives
